title: The Best Way To Eat Healthy When You're Short On Time
summary: Many people assume that leftovers are unhealthy, but that’s not the case if you make smart choices. Rotating your vegetables will help you avoid falling into a pattern where you’re only eating one or two types of vegetables every week. Eating smaller meals throughout the day has been shown to increase feelings of fullness and prevent overeating at meals. Eating beans and Lentils are two of the healthiest protein sources you can eat, and you can use them to replace meat in tacos and burritos.

It\u2019s easier to make healthy choices when you know what\u2019s coming up instead of reacting to whatever happens to be in the fridge. It\u2019s also helpful to decide what you\u2019re going to eat before you enter the kitchen. Sometimes the mere act of opening the fridge can make it harder to stick to your healthy eating plan.
Most people make healthy meal plans on paper, but you can also use an online diet app like MyFitnessPal to streamline the process.`),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t Fear Leftovers"),mdx("p",null,"Many people assume that leftovers are unhealthy, but that\u2019s not the case if you make smart choices. Many foods can actually taste even better when they\u2019re reheated, which is helpful if you don\u2019t have the time or energy to cook a brand new meal."),mdx("p",null,"If you\u2019re eating leftover veggies, be sure to reheat them long enough to kill any bacteria that might have grown while the food was sitting in the fridge. Foods like pasta, rice, and potatoes can all be re-heated in a microwave, but other items may require a stovetop re-heat."),mdx("p",null,"Many experts recommend eating leftover foods as a way to lower the cost of your diet, but be sure to make healthy choices when you\u2019re re-heating. Avoid things like fried foods, fatty sauces, and heavy gravies that weren\u2019t healthy to begin with."),mdx("h2",null,"Rotate Your Veggies"),mdx("p",null,`Not all vegetables are created equally. While some are high in fiber and low in calories, others are heavy and rich in calories. It\u2019s not uncommon to see people falling into a rut where they eat the same vegetables every week. That\u2019s fine if you\u2019re eating healthy options, but it\u2019s very easy to gradually slip into a pattern where you\u2019re only eating root vegetables. Root vegetables are important, but they shouldn\u2019t be the only vegetables in your diet.
For example, you might want to include peppers in your diet once a week. Or, if you enjoy cabbages, you could make a point of eating it at least a couple times a month. Rotating your vegetables will help you avoid getting bored with your meals. It\u2019ll also help you avoid falling into a pattern where you\u2019re only eating one or two types of vegetables.`),mdx("h2",null,"Go For High-Fiber Vegetables"),mdx("p",null,`Fiber is important for healthy digestion and blood sugar balance, but some vegetables have much more of it than others. In fact, some veggies have no fiber at all, so it\u2019s important to choose wisely.
Vegetables like kale and broccoli are great sources of fiber, but you\u2019ll find fewer of these nutrients in lettuce and avocado. It\u2019s best to focus on eating plenty of veggies like kale and collard greens, as well as whole grains like oats and barley.
Vegetables and grains are two of the easiest ways to boost your daily fiber intake. It\u2019s also helpful to avoid eating too many whole grains, as they can be rich in calories.`),mdx("h2",null,"Try Beans and Lentils"),mdx("p",null,`Some people avoid eating beans and legumes because they aren\u2019t sure how to prepare them. But they happen to be two of the healthiest foods you can eat. In fact, beans have been shown to have just as many health benefits as other protein sources.
You can try eating beans in a variety of different ways, including eating them in bean burritos, salads, and in chili. Lentils are another high-protein food that can be used in a number of different dishes. You can try them in soups or stews, or you can use them to replace meat in tacos and burritos.`),mdx("h2",null,"Keep Healthy Snacks Handy"),mdx("p",null,`Keep a variety of healthy snacks handy so that you can avoid overeating at meals. It\u2019s important to eat throughout the day, but it\u2019s also easy to overeat when you\u2019re eating more meals.
For example, if you eat three meals a day and each meal includes a baked potato, you\u2019ll be getting far more carbs than you need in one day. It\u2019s important to avoid that by keeping healthy snacks nearby so that you can eat just enough to avoid feeling hungry.
You can also try eating smaller meals more frequently throughout the day. Eating more often has been shown to increase feelings of fullness and prevent overeating at one sitting.`),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t Be Afraid Of The Fridge"),mdx("p",null,`Some people are under the impression that eating vegetables out of the fridge is bad for you. While it\u2019s true that vegetables lose some of their nutritional value when they\u2019re kept in the fridge, they\u2019re still very healthy.
You can help keep vegetables fresh by cutting them up and placing them in a plastic container with a lid. You can also buy vegetables that have been pre-cut, which makes it easier to use them in a meal.
It\u2019s important to remember that eating fresh food is always better than eating something that\u2019s been sitting in your fridge for a long time.`),mdx("h2",null,"Try A Smaller Plate"),mdx("p",null,`Eating off a smaller plate is one way to trick yourself into eating less food. It\u2019s an old trick, but it works: Studies have found that people tend to eat less when they eat off smaller plates.
If you don\u2019t want to buy a new set of dishes, you can still eat off a smaller plate. Just put a folded cloth or paper towel in the center of your plate. It should be about one-third the size of your normal plate. This extra space will help you eat less without really noticing the difference.`),mdx("h2",null,"Bottom line"),mdx("p",null,"Now that you know how to eat healthy on the go, there\u2019s no excuse to fall short on your diet. Nobody has the time to spend hours in the kitchen cooking elaborate meals, but it\u2019s not hard to grab a quick snack or salad while you\u2019re out and about."),mdx("p",null,"We all lead busy lives with lots of obligations outside of work or school: we have friends, family members, and partners that we need to spend time with on a regular basis. It doesn\u2019t leave much room for eating right. Fortunately, there are lots of ways to keep your diet in check while also fitting in your hectic schedule."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

For some it might be a small splurge, for others, a luxury they can\u2019t afford. Either way, eating healthy on a budget isn\u2019t easy. Eating less processed and pre-packaged foods is one way to cut costs and stay healthy at the same time. Another way is to get creative and buy things when they are on special or use cheaper alternatives like frozen or canned versions of fruits and veggies instead of the fresh ones. There are many ways to do this that won\u2019t leave you feeling deprived while still giving your body what it needs to be healthy.
For those who eat a lot of fast food or find themselves eating unhealthy because it\u2019s cheaper than buying wholesome foods, these tips will help you make healthier choices while saving money at the same time.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

But how can you make sure you succeed this time? Planning and preparation are key to any endeavor, including sticking to your healthy eating goals in the New Year. Thinking ahead and making a plan will help you avoid pitfalls and stay on track. After all, it\u2019s not about failing once but rather keeping failure at bay so it doesn\u2019t creep up again next year.
Many people struggle with their eating habits because they lack structure or fail to plan ahead. That\u2019s why creating a strategy is essential if you want to maintain this commitment for good. Whether it\u2019s going on a diet, cutting out certain foods or reducing your intake of fats, proteins or carbs \u2013 there are different ways how you can achieve your goals. In fact, many people see their daily drive to work or school as a time for peace and quiet. After all, what could possibly be stressful about getting from point A to point B?
It\u2019s true that your commute isn\u2019t inherently stressful. In theory, it\u2019s just a short period of time each day when you go from home to work (or vise versa). It\u2019s not like we all have hours to cook and prep the perfect meal after a long day at school or work. So how are we supposed to eat right when there\u2019s barely time to even pick up fast food? Well, the answer isn\u2019t as hard as you might think\u2026 If you are ready to take control of your diet, then read on\u2026
If you feel like your life is always in hyper-speed and there\u2019s never enough hours in the day to get everything done, then you know exactly how these pressures can lead to unhealthy eating habits. But that doesn\u2019t have to be the case forever. Even with a busy schedule, it is totally possible for anyone to eat healthy meals regularly.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

In our fast-paced world, it can be challenging to stick with a diet or eating plan. It\u2019t not easy staying motivated and sticking with a diet when there are so many temptations around us. Eating the right foods is important for our long-term health. There are so many benefits of eating healthy foods and it may help you feel better, have more energy, and even live longer. However, many people find it difficult to maintain their eating habits because their life is full of distractions like work, school, and family obligations.
